string_table.string: To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

search.slidetext: select a term to learn more. abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

automaticity this means that information is recalled and used automatically with minimal conscious effort. this starts to occur after extensive practise. in relation to reading, it is the ability to rapidly, effortlessly and accurately recognise or decode words on sight. analytic phonics an approach to the teaching of reading that starts at the word level, rather than the sound (phoneme) level. alphabetic principle the understanding that spoken language is made up of sounds and sounds can be matched to written letters. alternative spellings alternative spellings are the various configurations of letters (graphemes) that represent one of the 44 phonemes in english, such as the <a>, <ai>, <ay> and <a_e> graphemes to represent the long /a/ sound. alliteration the repetition of the first phoneme in several words in a sentence. e.g., the bee buzzed busily among the flowers. tongue twisters are examples of alliteration. a abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz alliteration alternative spellings alphabetic principle analytic phonics automaticity
blending blending is the ability to join speech sounds (phonemes) together to make words. b abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz blending

cvc cvc is an acronym for consonant-vowel-consonant words. e.g., the word cat has a consonant-vowel-consonant (cvc) correspondence. cvc words are often among the first types of words students begin segmenting and blending due to their regular patterning. as students develop with phonics, they will work with more complex patterns such as, cvcc (consonant-vowel-consonant-consonant), ccvc (consonant-consonant-vowel-consonant) and ccvcc (consonant-consonant-vowel-consonant-consonant) words like gift, frog and drink. comprehension comprehension is the ability to make meaning from something that has been read, seen or heard. it relates to spoken, written and visual texts. it is an active and complex process. consonant digraph two consonants that represent one sound. for example, /sh/ in shop or fish. consonant clusters two or three letters (graphemes) making two or three sounds. e.g., the first three letters of street are a consonant cluster. can be referred to as blends. c consonant clusters consonant digraph comprehension cvc abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

double consonant two-letter graphemes of the same consonant that represent one sound in a single syllable word. for example, <ff>, <ll>, <ss> or <zz> in puff, will, hiss and buzz. diphthong a gliding vowel, where the first of two vowels glides into another to form a single vowel sound in a syllable - /oy/ /oi/ /ow/ /ou/ - boy, coil, frown, ground. digraphs two letters that combine to represent one sound (phoneme). for example, /sh/ in ship or /oa/ in boat. decoding decoding occurs when a student uses their knowledge of phoneme/grapheme correspondence to accurately read a word. decodable text texts specifically written for beginning readers. they support students who are learning to blend and segment sounds due to their large percentage of decodable words. they increase in complexity as students learn more of the alphabetic code. d decodable text decoding digraphs diphthong double consonant abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

explicit teaching a method of teaching that breaks down what students need to learn into smaller learning outcomes and models each step (aero, 2022). encoding encoding is the process of hearing a spoken sound (phoneme) and writing it down using an appropriate letter or letter combination (grapheme). e encoding explicit teaching abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

floss rule a spelling rule that states: when a one-syllable word ends with a short vowel followed by /f/, /l/ or /s/, you double the final consonant. fluency fluency is reading expressively with accuracy and at a purposeful pace. f floss rule fluency abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

grapheme a written symbol (a letter or letters) that represents a sound (phoneme). when students say a sound, it is a phoneme. however, when they write that sound, it is a grapheme. g abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz grapheme

high-frequency words words that are commonly used in written text (e.g. and, it, was, because, or said). some high-frequency words are easily decodable (e.g. and), but many are not as they do not use regular or common letter patterns (e.g. said). h abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz high-frequency words

irregular word irregular words, sometimes called tricky words are those that cannot be decoded using the most likely grapheme to phoneme correspondence, or do not follow a phonetic pattern at all. examples include said, was or what. i irregular word abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
j abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
k abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

the term used to refer to vowels where the pronunciation of the sound is the same as its letter name. for example, the // in alien. a long vowel sound is typically held for longer than a short vowel sound. these often appear in words ending in a silent <e> (e.g., make) or words ending in a vowel (e.g., he or no). long vowel l abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz long vowel

morphology refers to the way words are formed and relate to one another. it is the study of words and their parts. morpheme morphemes, such as prefixes, suffixes and base words, are defined as the smallest meaningful units of meaning in a word. manipulating phonemes deleting and substituting phonemes to create new words. this can be done with initial, end and middle sounds. m abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz manipulating phonemes morpheme morphology
n abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

orthographic mapping orthographic mapping involves the formation of letter-sound connections to bond the spellings, pronunciations and meanings of specific words in memory. it explains how students learn to read words by sight, to spell words from memory and to acquire vocabulary words from print. onset the onset of a word is any consonant sounds that precede the vowel. e.g., the word 'top' has t as the onset and op as the rime. the word 'spy' has sp as the onset and y as the rime. o abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz onset orthographic mapping

prosody prosody is the tune and rhythm of speech and how these features contribute to meaning. fluent readers chunk words together in appropriate, meaningful phrases, and use their voice to convey and enhance the meaning of texts. prefix prefixes are morphemes that attach to the beginning of a root/base word. e.g.. the 'dis' in disregard. phonological awareness the understanding that spoken language (speech) can be broken down into smaller parts and manipulated. it consists of five sub-skills: spoken word awareness, responsiveness to rhyme and alliteration, awareness of spoken syllables, understanding of onset and rime and phonemic awareness. phonics phonics is the matching of sounds (phonemes) in spoken language to the letters (graphemes) that represent them in writing. it is also the term used for the teaching of reading and spelling by learning the relationships between phonemes and graphemes. phonemic awareness the ability to identify and manipulate the individual sounds (phonemes) in spoken language. it involves blending, segmenting and/or deleting the sounds in words. phoneme the smallest unit of sound in a language. there are 44 phonemes in the english language system. the word top has three phonemes, /t/ /o/ /p/. the words top and pop differ by one phoneme, the /p/ and the /t/. p phoneme phonemic awareness phonics phonological awareness prefix prosody abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
quadgraph a quadgraph is four letters that combine to correspond to one sound (phoneme). e.g., the <augh> in taught or the <ough> in tough. q abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz quadgraph

rime the rime is the vowel and any consonants that come after the onset (if there is one). for example, the word cat has /c/ as the onset and /at/ as the rime. rimes can sometimes be referred to as word families, as they have common endings or patterns in words. rhyme the repetition of similar sounds at the end of two or more words. for example, pop and top, or stair and pear. rhyming is a literary device often used to support the rhythm and the way words sound when read aloud. it is a useful tool when teaching phonics to help students identify repeating sounds. reading reading is the process of decoding (sounds and symbols), interpreting and critically analysing to construct meaning from a wide range of texts (written, visual, print and non-print). r-controlled vowel vowel immediately followed by <r> and which is no longer pronounced as a long or short vowel. for example, /or/ as in horn, /ar/ as in car or /ir/ as in bird. r abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz r-controlled vowel reading rhyme rime

systematic synthetic phonics systematic synthetic phonics approach is an approach to teaching phonics that systematically introduces phonemes and corresponding graphemes so students can build them into words. systematic phonics a systematic phonics approach requires a logical and sequential order to explicitly teach grapheme-phoneme correspondences. synthetic phonics an approach to the teaching of phonics that starts at the sound (phoneme) level, focusing on the synthesising or blending of phonemes (sounds) to make a word. syllabification syllables are sometimes referred to as the beats in a word. all syllables must contain a vowel or vowel-like sound. suffix suffixes are morphemes that attach to the end of a root/base word. e.g., the '-ed' in jumped. split vowel digraph a specific type of digraph where two vowels are split by a consonant. the second vowel is always <e>. common examples are <a_e> (as in cake), <i_e> (as in five) or <o_e> (as in code). split digraph a split digraph is two graphemes (letters) that make one phoneme (sound) and are split by a consonant. the <a_e> in cake is a split digraph. spelling spelling concerns the orthography of print. spelling involves phonics and other strategies, such as common graphemic sequences, visual strategies, such as common graphemic patterns, and morphemic strategies, such as how words represent meaning (nation or nationality). sight words words that students have committed to memory and can recognise on sight. students do not need a decoding strategy to decode these words. sentence a group of words that convey a complete thought or idea. segmenting segmenting is the ability to hear, say and write words by isolating the individual sounds from a given word. short vowel the term used for vowel sounds that are made when the mouth and tongue are in a relaxed position. they are typically quicker sounds than long vowels. they usually appear in syllables that are stressed and ending in a consonant. for example, // in cat. schwa unstressed vowel sound. the most common vowel sound in english that can be represented by any vowel grapheme for example, seven, lemon, the, family, elephant. s abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz schwa segmenting sentence short vowel sight words spelling split digraph split vowel digraph suffix syllabification synthetic phonics systematic phonics systematic synthetic phonics
trigraphs a trigraph is three letters that combine to correspond to one sound (phoneme), for example, the <dge> in bridge, or <igh> in sigh are trigraphs. t abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz trigraphs
u abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

vowel digraph two vowels that represent one sound. for example, <oa> in boat representing the // sound. vowel sounds that are made when the breath is unobstructed. they can be represented by single vowel letters and the letter <y>, or letter combinations (<ee>, <aw>, <igh>, <ear>, <ough>). there are several types of vowel sounds: short vowel sounds: // as in bat long vowel sounds: // as in alien /r/ controlled vowels: /or/ as in horn or /ar/ as in car <y> as a vowel sound: long // sound in fly or cycle vocabulary the body of words used in a particular language. a student's vocabulary consists of words they know, understand and can use in context. v abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz vocabulary vowel vowel digraph

word a word is a unit of language that carries meaning and can stand alone. whole-language approach a whole-language approach to reading is a method of teaching students to read by recognising words through repeated exposure as whole pieces of language, rather than being broken down into parts. w whole-language approach word abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
x abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
y abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
z abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
